channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Japanese Team Dominates Competition to Create Rescue Robots
item.description: A team of Japanese roboticists was among eight selected to move on to compete for a chance at the $2 million prize in an international competition to pave the way for a new generation of rescue robots.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN MARKOFF
item.media:description: The Johnson Space Center’s Valkyrie robot competes at completing a task, closing a valve, at the Darpa Robotics Challenge.

item.title: The Lede: A Twitter Message About AIDS, Followed by a Firing and an Apology
item.description: A Manhattan public relations executive loses her job after a post on Twitter about AIDS, race and Africa created an online furor.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: Bangladeshi Factory Owners Charged in Fire That Killed 112
item.description: The case that came to symbolize the appalling working conditions in the textile industry is the first in which the authorities have sought to prosecute factory owners in the garment industry.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Delowar Hossain, owner of Tazreen Fashions Ltd. He has said that just three stories of his garment plant were legal.

item.title: Antigovernment Protesters Vow to Block Elections and ‘Shut Down’ Thailand
item.description: Demonstrators in Bangkok vowed to disrupt elections scheduled for Feb. 2 in their campaign to rid Thailand of its most influential political family.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Egyptian Activists Sentenced to 3 Years in Prison for Protests
item.description: The three well-known activists, Ahmed Maher, Mohamed Adel and Ahmed Douma, were convicted under a new law seen as part of the military-backed government’s effort to curb dissent.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: From left, Ahmed Maher (in hat), Ahmed Douma and Mohamed Adel in a Cairo court on Sunday.

item.title: After Freedom, Russian Dissident Says He Won’t Enter Politics
item.description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, a former billionaire and critic of President Vladimir V. Putin who was imprisoned for a decade in Russia, said in Berlin that he would continue to be socially active and work on behalf of prisoners.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky the museum at Checkpoint Charlie in Berlin on Sunday before his first news conference since his release.

item.title: Libyan Army Base Is Hit by a Deadly Suicide Bomb Attack
item.description: At least six people were killed in the blast in Barsis, about 30 miles outside Benghazi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Michiaki Takahashi, 85, Who Tamed Chickenpox, Dies
item.description: Dr. Takahashi, a researcher of measles and polio viruses, was spurred to action when his 3-year-old son fell ill.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: Attack on U.S. Aircraft Foils Evacuation in South Sudan
item.description: Four service members were wounded on Saturday after aircraft flying into South Sudan to evacuate American citizens were attacked and forced to turn back, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Pardoned Russian Tycoon Is Free to Start Planning His Future
item.description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky spent his first full day of freedom reconnecting with his family and meeting with German officials in Berlin amid speculation about what he might do next.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: With Punishments or Pardons, Putin Shows He Is in Control
item.description: He has demonstrated an ability not only to wield the executive power of the Kremlin but also to bend the legislative and judicial branches of government to his will.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is keeping his foes off balance with actions like the pardon on Friday of the tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.

item.title: Favela Lodging
item.description: The residents of Rio’s slums are renting out rooms to tourists and soccer fans from around the globe.

item.title: Turkish Premier Blames Foreign Envoys for Turmoil
item.description: On Saturday morning, four pro-government newspapers suggested that the United States was behind an escalating corruption investigation that has touched people in the prime minister’s inner circle.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: Somali Parliament Approves New Prime Minister
item.description: The Somali president, Hassan Sheik Mohamud, nominated Abdiweli Sheikh Ahmed Mohamed after lawmakers forced out the former prime minister in a no-confidence vote.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Morsi to Stand Trial on Role in ’11 Uprising
item.description: An Egyptian judge ordered ousted President Mohamed Morsi to stand trial on charges that he worked with foreign militants to free prisoners during the 2011 uprising.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MARWA NASSER

item.title: The Lede: NASA’s Tweets and Video of Emergency Spacewalk
item.description: Video and Twitter updates from NASA of astronauts fixing a cooling pump on the exterior of the International Space Station.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Political Strife in South Sudan Sets Off Ethnic Violence
item.description: Longstanding tensions between ethnic groups could ultimately tear the new nation apart, activists and diplomats fear.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: Women jostled to get water at the United Nations compound in South Sudan, where thousands have sought refuge from violence.

item.title: Indian Envoy Is Transferred to U.N. Post
item.description: The new position could protect the diplomat, Devyani Khobragade, 39, the deputy consul general in New York, from charges she underpaid a housekeeper.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside the Indian Consulate in New York on Friday after Devyani Khobragade, an Indian diplomat, was accused of underpaying a housekeeper.

item.title: 18 Soldiers in Iraq Are Killed During Raid on Rebel Group’s Training Camp
item.description: An Iraqi Army commander was among those killed by suicide bombers and roadside explosions during a raid on the training camp of a Qaeda affiliate.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Vandals in Sweden Target Christmas Goat
item.description: For the 27th time, a giant straw goat meant to symbolize Christmas spirit was burned down in Gavle, Sweden.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Now Taking World Cup Bookings, Rio’s Slums
item.description: With hotel rooms in short supply, the residents of Rio de Janeiro’s favelas, or slums, are renting out their homes to visiting soccer fans from around the globe.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Isom Hightower from San Francisco, in the bottom bunk bed, pays around $11 a night in Rocinha.

item.title: Thai Opposition Party Will Boycott February Elections as Large Protests Continue
item.description: The leader of the Democrat Party, which has its base in Thailand’s old moneyed elite, said the elections would be the “same old power grab” by the governing party and its allies.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: The leader of Thailand's Democrat Party, former Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, spoke during a news conference in Bangkok on Saturday.

item.title: For Most Young Refugees From Syria, School Is as Distant as Home
item.description: Of the more than two million Syrian refugees in the region, about 865,000 are children, and most of them are not enrolled in school, Unicef said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Irish Try to Eradicate Ghosts of a Housing Crash
item.description: A nation is trying to clean up after thousands of homes that, after the housing bubble burst, were never finished or are substandard.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Unoccupied houses in Cloonfad, a small town in the county of Roscommon in Ireland.

item.title: Chinese Security Official Is Focus of Corruption Inquiry
item.description: The investigation of Li Dongsheng, a vice minister of public security, is part of a widening inquiry into China’s top officials under President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Color China Photo, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Li Dongsheng, pictured in 2007, is being investigated by the Communist Party of China.
